clean_story:
Lightweight. Perfect bounce.
The name "ping pong ball" comes from the sound it makes—ping when struck, pong when it bounces.


Most people see it as just a small white ball.
But making one requires precision—like baking a cake where every ingredient must be exact.


It starts with celluloid, a plastic-like material invented in the 1800s.
Workers mix it with camphor (a waxy substance from trees) to make it flexible.
The mixture is pressed into a thin sheet, then cut into half-spheres—like slicing an orange in two.


The halves are glued together with a special adhesive, leaving a tiny seam.
After drying, the balls are tumbled in a drum to smooth the edges—like polishing rocks in a river.


Finally, they’re tested for weight (2. 7 grams) and bounce (24 cm drop, 23 cm rebound).
If one fails, it’s melted down and reused.


Plastic alternatives.
Olympic-grade standards.
Why dimples matter.
